citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there were five adult dogs had untreated dental disease. Ella Love, an 7-year-old female Cocker
Spaniel, (m/c# 99000001621716) had excessive
tarter build up on her molars and a lesion above the canine tooth. Her molars were incased with tarter and a the gum
around the incisor appeared black in addition to redness and swelling. Bailey, a 4-year-old female Havanese, (m/c
991001001826584) had excessive tarter on the canines and molars. The molars and incisors were three quarters covered
in tarter on both sides of the mouth. The gums were red and swollen. Cowgirl, a 5-yearold female Beagle/Aussie mix,
(m/c# 99000000139098) had excessive tarter on her canines and molars on both sides. The gums are red and swollen
with a lesion above the left canine. Pete, a 6-year-old male Beagle, (m/c#990000336575 ) had excessive tarter mainly on
his incisors with red and swollen gums. Cloud, a 3-year-old male Shiba (m/c#990000007199898) was unable to be
examined due to aggression. The State of Missouri hands on examination form, completed by the Attending Veterinarian
on 5.9.2023, indicated that the above animals were diagnosed with dental disease requiring a dental. The licensee
relayed that the dogs have not received a dental to date. Teeth and/or gum problems can be painful, can affect the ability
to eat, and can result in tooth loss. Not following the AV’s treatment plan can result in the animals’ diagnosed dental
disease increasing in severity and discomfort. The licensee must ensure that the Attending Veterinarian’s treatment plans
are followed at all times.
To be corrected by: 4.18.24

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection, a female Havanese (microchip number 956000012458530) exhibited frequent head shaking. Both
internal portions of the ears were exhibiting a large growth obstructing the canal with the build up of a waxy brown
material. Additionally, the right ear was exhibiting some small areas of redness. Animal health issues left untreated can be
painful. Daily observation shall be conducted to recognize any health or well being issues and convey them to the
attending veterinarian. The communication with the AV must be timely and must relay accurate information on problems
of animal health, behavior, and well being. Additionally, the licensee shall have the aforementioned dog examined by a
licensed veterinarian.
To be corrected by: 4.18.24

At time of inspection, the record of acquisition reflected the inventory to be 48 total adults. However, the actual inventory
of adult animals housed at the facility was totaled at 62. Record keeping is an important part of animal husbandry and
tracking/tracing purposes. The licensee shall update the record of acquisition to reflect the accurate number of adults
housed at the facility. The records shall include: the name and address of the person from whom a dog or cat was
purchased or otherwise acquired whether or not the person is required to be licensed or registered under the Act.The
USDA license or registration number of the person if he or she is licensed or registered under the Act. The vehicle license
number and State, and the driver's license number (or photographic identification card for non-drivers issued by a State)
and State of the person, if he or she is not licensed or registered under the Act. The name and address of the person to
whom a dog or cat was sold or given and that person's license or registration number if he or she is licensed or registered
under the Act. The date a dog or cat was acquired or disposed of, including by euthanasia. The official USDA tag number
or tattoo assigned to a dog or cat. A description of each dog or cat which shall include:
The species and breed or type;
The sex;
The date of birth or approximate age;
The color and any distinctive markings;
To be corrected by: 4.24.24

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
At time of inspection, there was an accumulation of excreta and molded food waste compressed into the grooves of the
corrugated type flooring on the indoor portion of the "reefer" style facility. The licensee could not recall the last time the
indoor portion of the facility had been cleaned or sanitized. Additionally, the outdoor portion of the aforementioned building
and the other sheltered facility had not been washed down or spot cleaned since 4.15.2024 according to the licensee.
Cleaning and sanitation is important part of animal husbandry as to ensure the health and well-being of the animals
housed. The licensee must ensure that excreta and food waste are removed from primary enclosures daily; and additional
cleaning and sanitization must be performed as required in this section in order to prevent accumulation of feces and food
waste and to reduce disease hazards, pests, insects and odors.
To be corrected by: 04.19.24
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Licensee.
n

2.75(a)(1) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
At time of inspection, the record of acquisition reflected the inventory to be 48 total adults. However, the actual inventory 
of adult animals housed at the facility was totaled at 62. Record keeping is an important part of animal husbandry and 
tracking/tracing purposes. The licensee shall update the record of acquisition to reflect the accurate number of adults 
housed at the facility. The records shall include: the name and address of the person from whom a dog or cat was 
purchased or otherwise acquired whether or not the person is required to be licensed or registered under the Act.The 
USDA license or registration number of the person if he or she is licensed or registered under the Act. The vehicle license 
number and State, and the driver's license number (or photographic identification card for non-drivers issued by a State) 
and State of the person, if he or she is not licensed or registered under the Act. The name and address of the person to 
whom a dog or cat was sold or given and that person's license or registration number if he or she is licensed or registered 
under the Act. The date a dog or cat was acquired or disposed of, including by euthanasia. The official USDA tag number 
or tattoo assigned to a dog or cat. A description of each dog or cat which shall include: 
 The species and breed or type; 
 The sex; 
 The date of birth or approximate age; 
 The color and any distinctive markings; 
 
To be corrected by: 4.24.24 
3.11(a) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
At time of inspection, there was an accumulation of excreta and molded food waste compressed into the grooves of the 
corrugated type flooring on the indoor portion of the "reefer" style facility. The licensee could not recall the last time the 
indoor portion of the facility had been cleaned or sanitized. Additionally, the outdoor portion of the aforementioned building 
and the other sheltered facility had not been washed down or spot cleaned since 4.15.2024 according to the licensee. 
Cleaning and sanitation is important part of animal husbandry as to ensure the health and well-being of the animals 
housed. The licensee must ensure that excreta and food waste are removed from primary enclosures daily; and additional 
cleaning and sanitization must be performed as required in this section in order to prevent accumulation of feces and food 
waste and to reduce disease hazards, pests, insects and odors. 
 
To be corrected by: 04.19.24 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with Licensee.
